11.text:
Jim: I didn't believe that I had it as bad
as it seemed.

19.text:
Hilary: I wasn't surprised. I didn't want
to particularly hear it, but was glad there

23.text:
was a reason for why I'd been struggling so
much at work.

26.text:
Rusty: I don't think it worried me. Because
I think I felt perfectly okay.

34.text:
Kathryn Smith: Welcome to The dementia guide.
This guide is for anyone who has recently

41.text:
been told they have dementia. It will also
be useful to close family members and friends,

46.text:
as it includes information for people who
might be starting to take on a role as a carer.

50.text:
You will find information to help you understand
more about dementia as well as some practical

54.text:
things you can do to live well now and make
plans for the future.

58.text:
Being told that you have dementia can make
you feel a range of emotions. The news might

62.text:
come as a shock or for some people, it might
bring a sense of relief, as it provides and

66.text:
explanation for the problems they've been
having. It can also have a big impact on family

71.text:
and friends.
My family and I have personally been affected

74.text:
by dementia, with both my granddad and aunt
being diagnosed. I understand some of the

79.text:
difficulties and challenges people face in
coming to terms with the diagnosis. And figuring

83.text:
out how to make adjustments to everyday life
and access support. My family have taken great

88.text:
comfort in the information support they've
received, which has really helped to make

91.text:
the best choices for their care.
It is important to know that you aren't alone.

96.text:
About 800,000 people in the UK have dementia.
It is possible to live well with dementia,

101.text:
and there is support available for you and
your family. If you can, talk to friends and

105.text:
family about how you're feeling. Other people
need to understand what you're going through.

110.text:
They might be finding things hard too. So
talking to them can help both you and them.

115.text:
There are also specialist health and social
care professionals you can talk to for support.

120.text:
You'll find information about Alzheimer's
Society Services later on in this guide. Alternatively

125.text:
you can phone our National Dementia Helpline
on 0300 222 1122.

135.text:
Please take your time watching the various
sections of this guide. You will hear from

140.text:
a range of people, including health and social
care professionals and people who are living

145.text:
with dementia and their close family. It is
possible to live well with dementia and you

150.text:
don't have to face it alone.
Brenda: We're a strong couple together. We're

203.text:
very positive in everything we try to do.
We were absolutely devastated.

209.text:
Ann: For me it was a relief really because
I felt once he was diagnosed it was just good

215.text:
to know that there was a reason for it. I
don't think he found it so much of a relief

220.text:
because I don't think he really believed there
was much wrong with his memory.

223.text:
Hilary: A lot of people say, ‘what's the
point in having a diagnosis if there's no

228.text:
cure?’ And it does make you wonder, but
for me yes I'm glad I got the diagnosis. At

236.text:
least with the diagnosis you can make – well
you can try and make plans for what you're

241.text:
going to do for the next however long you've
got.

248.text:
Dan Harwood: Dementia is an overall term for
a range of conditions. It isn't just one specific

258.text:
disease. Most people have heard of Alzheimer's
disease which is just one type of dementia.

264.text:
Despite what many people think, dementia is
not a normal part of ageing. Dementia occurs

270.text:
when the brain is affected by disease.
Dementia affects everyone differently and

283.text:
can cause a wide range of symptoms. These
can include problems with memory, thinking,

289.text:
concentration, and language. People may become
confused or struggle with how they see things.

296.text:
Dementia can also cause changes in mood or
emotions and affect how someone behaves. Unfortunately,

303.text:
dementia is progressive and symptoms will
get worse over time.

315.text:
There are over 100 types of dementia. The
most common are Alzheimer's disease and vascular

321.text:
dementia. Sometimes, people have a combination
of both, which is called mixed dementia. Less

328.text:
common types of dementia are dementia with
Lewy bodies and frontotemporal dementia.

335.text:
At the moment, scientists don't know why some
people get dementia. It's known that ageing,

348.text:
genes, health and lifestyle all play a part.
There are 800,000 people living with dementia

355.text:
in the UK. The chance of developing it increases
rapidly with age. One in 14 people over 65

362.text:
years of age and one in 6 people over 80 has
dementia. So most people with dementia are

368.text:
older, but dementia does also affect younger
people of working age. People who are diagnosed

373.text:
with dementia who are under 65 are said to
have early onset or young onset dementia.

379.text:
Peter: Well I can remember it quite distinctly.
Because Hilary came home and I could see in

387.text:
her face there was something wrong. I said
to her, ‘what's wrong?’ She said, ‘I

395.text:
might as well tell you, I've got Alzheimer's’.
Hilary: Looking back – I can go back 15

404.text:
years – and see things starting to change.
But not to a level where it bothered me. The

411.text:
key thing that made me go back to the doctor
when I got the diagnosis last year was I'd

418.text:
had a meeting – a pretty intensive meeting.
It was a one to one meeting with somebody

422.text:
I hadn't met before. A few weeks later I was
at a conference and this person came up to

430.text:
me and said, ‘hello Hilary how are you?’
And I would have sworn I had never met that

435.text:
person before. I had – I just didn't recognise
him. That freaked me out a fair bit, having

442.text:
sat opposite somebody for two hours having
an intense conversation with them and then

446.text:
not recognising them just a couple of weeks
later. That was what finally prompted me to

450.text:
go back last year.
And as a result of the tests and the brain

454.text:
scan I got the diagnosis of early-onset Alzheimer's.
Dan Harwood: To find out more about dementia,

466.text:
visit alzheimers.org.uk/aboutdementia
Rusty: You can live your life with the treatment

515.text:
you get. I suppose the drugs that they give
us are obviously doing us good. I know I'm

521.text:
taking medicine but I just don't think about
it. I think it must be helpful because I really

529.text:
don't have too many worries about it.
Dan Harwood: There is currently no known cure

540.text:
for dementia, although there is lots of research
going on to find one. However, there are drugs

546.text:
that will help to treat some of the symptoms
of dementia or stop them progressing for a

551.text:
while. This depends on what type of dementia
someone has.

563.text:
People have Alzheimer's disease or mixed dementia,
where Alzheimer's is the main cause are usually

569.text:
offered one of four drugs – donepezil, rivastigmine,
galantamine or memantine. These are widely

576.text:
known by the brand names, Aricept, Exelon,
Reminyl and Ebixa but there are others. These

584.text:
drugs all help to tackle the physical changes
in the brain that cause dementia.

589.text:
The first three, donepezil, rivastigmine and
galantamine are usually prescribed to people

595.text:
who have mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease
or mixed dementia. Some people find these

601.text:
drugs lessen their symptoms for a while. Benefits
can include improvements in motivation, anxiety

608.text:
levels, confidence, daily living, memory and
thinking. These drugs will initially be prescribed

614.text:
by a specialist, such as a consultant at the
memory clinic.

619.text:
If one of these three drugs causes problematic
side effects, it is possible to switch and

624.text:
try one of the others. People who have moderate
Alzheimer's disease but can't take any of

629.text:
the three drugs we've just talked about, perhaps
because of side effects, might be offered

633.text:
memantine, known as the brand name Ebixa.
It's also become more common to be offered

638.text:
memantine in the later stages of Alzheimer's
disease when symptoms become severe.

644.text:
The benefits of memantine are that it can
temporarily slow down the progression of symptoms

650.text:
in people in the middle and later stages of
Alzheimer's disease. It may also help with

655.text:
agitation or aggressive behaviour which are
more common in more advanced dementia.

669.text:
The last four drugs I've just described that
are used for Alzheimer's disease aren't effective

673.text:
for people with vascular dementia. They are
only given to people with vascular dementia

678.text:
when this is part of a mixed dementia with
Alzheimer's disease. It may be possible to

683.text:
slow down the progression of vascular dementia
by taking drugs that treat the underlying

689.text:
conditions. So the GP will often prescribe
drugs for people with vascular dementia who

694.text:
are at risk of having a stroke or who have
high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes

700.text:
or heart problems. In many cases, the person
will already be taking some of these medicines.

714.text:
If they are experiencing distressing symptoms
such as hallucinations, which is where people

719.text:
see things that aren't there, or delusions,
which is when they believe things that aren't

724.text:
true, someone with dementia with Lewy bodies
might benefit from one of the three anti-Alzheimer's

730.text:
drugs, donepezil, rivastigmine or galantamine.
In frontotemporal dementia, the anti-Alzheimer's

745.text:
drugs haven't been shown to offer any benefits
and may even be harmful. Because of this,

750.text:
they shouldn't be prescribed. It's common
for people with behavioural variant frontotemporal

756.text:
dementia to be prescribed anti-depressant
medication. This can help to reduce some of

762.text:
the inappropriate obsessive or compulsive
behaviours that are common symptoms of frontotemporal

768.text:
dementia.
As with lots of medication, drugs to treat

779.text:
dementia can cause some side effects. For
example, donepezil can cause nausea or diarrhoea.

787.text:
For more information on side effects, talk
to your GP.

800.text:
Drugs are not the only way to treat or manage
the symptoms of dementia. There are many other

804.text:
things that can help people to live well.
Talking therapies, such as counselling or

816.text:
psychotherapy give people the chance to speak
in confidence to a qualified professional

822.text:
about problems or issues that might be bothering
them. They might help you to come to terms

826.text:
with the diagnosis and identify ways to live
well with dementia. They may also help with

832.text:
symptoms of depression or anxiety. Talking
therapies typically involve regular sessions

838.text:
with a therapist, either one to one or sometimes
in a group.

842.text:
They can be face to face or over the phone.
Some people will just have one session while

848.text:
the others will have therapy that continues
for many months. Alongside talking therapies

854.text:
there are other non-drug approaches that may
be helpful as dementia progresses.

859.text:
Some of the more commonly used ones are reminiscence
therapy and life story work and cognitive

865.text:
stimulation therapy.
Reminiscence work involves talking about things

878.text:
from the past using prompts such as photos,
familiar objects or music. It can be one to

884.text:
one or in a group. Life story work is usually
shared between the person with dementia and

891.text:
a family member, friend or support worker.
A scrap book or photo album is used to record

897.text:
details of the person's life. These techniques
particularly when done one on one can improve

904.text:
mood, wellbeing and some mental or cognitive
abilities such as memory.

909.text:
At the same time, they can help others to
focus on the person rather than their dementia.

916.text:
The services available and how to be referred
to one of them can vary around the country.

921.text:
Ask your GP, memory service or local Alzheimer's
Society for details of what is available in

927.text:
your local area.
Another non-drug option for people with dementia

940.text:
is complementary therapy. These therapies
are outside of conventional medicine and are

945.text:
used to treat or prevent illness and promote
health and wellbeing. Complementary therapy

952.text:
should be used alongside and not instead of
conventional medicines. Anyone thinking about

958.text:
trying these therapies should tell their GP.
Some examples of therapies that may help people

964.text:
with dementia are massage, aromatherapy, bright
light therapy where you sit in front of a

971.text:
light box, and music therapy.
Ann: I think I worry more about how Rusty's

988.text:
feeling in as much as he gets a bit depressed
with himself. I think that's probably my biggest

993.text:
worry. I think the fact that he worries about
he can't do things like he used to. Like he

999.text:
gets in a muddle if he tries to change plugs
and he can't get the television to work and

1004.text:
things that he's always been able to do. So
he gets a bit depressed about that side of

1007.text:
it.
Dan Harwood: It's quite common for people

1009.text:
with dementia to experience depression or
anxiety, especially in the early stages. People

1015.text:
who have vascular dementia or Parkinson's
disease dementia are more likely to experience

1020.text:
it than people with other types of dementia.
There are both drug and non-drug treatments

1033.text:
that can be used for depression and anxiety.
Anti-depressants work by correcting the level

1040.text:
of some chemicals in the brain. But research
has shown that common anti-depressants don't

1046.text:
work as well for depression in people with
dementia as they do for people that don't

1051.text:
have dementia.
It can take several weeks to notice the benefits

1056.text:
of taking an anti-depressant. Many people
experience some side effects to begin with,

1062.text:
but these usually lessen after a week or two.
There are other ways to treat depression that

1074.text:
don't involve taking drugs. These include
talking therapies such as counselling, reminiscence

1080.text:
activities and life story work. Other simple
things that can help with depression and anxiety

1088.text:
include keeping active, doing activities that
you enjoy, and talking to friends and family.

1093.text:
Eating a healthy diet and not having too much
alcohol or caffeine can also help.

1101.text:
To find out more about treatments for dementia,
visit alzheimers.org.uk/treatment

1142.text:
Hilary: We live for today don't we and enjoy
it. And enjoy it.

1157.text:
Jim: If life is still interesting then the
problem becomes diminished a bit.

1164.text:
Brenda: It's about stimulation, it's about
people doing what they've always done. Maybe

1168.text:
at a different level to what they've done
it, but actually still taking part seeing

1173.text:
their friends, going out and about and following
the interests they've always had. They won't

1178.text:
have the same enthusiasm but none of us do
as we get older anyway. But it's just managing

1184.text:
it and keeping up to date, not letting a person
drop out.

1193.text:
Alice Moody: Living with dementia is challenging
and you may feel angry or frustrated about

1204.text:
what's happening to you. Your plans for the
future might change, but dementia doesn't

1209.text:
change who you are as a person. A diagnosis
doesn't mean that you need to stop doing the

1216.text:
things that you enjoy, but you might have
to do them in a different way. It's important

1222.text:
to focus on the things you can and want to
do and try not to allow yourself to become

1227.text:
isolated.
Keeping busy with activities you enjoy may

1231.text:
help you to feel more confident.
Memory problems can be distressing. And it

1244.text:
may affect your confidence. There are several
things you could try. Try keeping a notebook

1251.text:
or a large week to view diary. Write down
in it things you want to remember like names

1257.text:
or to do lists. Keep it by the kettle or phone,
somewhere you gravitate towards so you get

1263.text:
used to referring to it. There are some technological
aids that people can find useful. These include

1270.text:
calendar clocks which show the date and the
day of the week. Keeping one of these clocks

1275.text:
next to the diary or weekly planner can help
you orientate yourself when checking appointments.

1281.text:
If you find you forget where things are, try
putting labels or pictures on cupboards or

1287.text:
drawers. This could help remind you what they
are. Or you could try keeping some things

1293.text:
from the kitchen that you use most often,
like a cup, a plate and a set of cutlery out

1298.text:
on a table visually.
You could also ask your pharmacist about putting

1303.text:
your pills into a disposable box called a
dosette box, which has the days of the week

1308.text:
marked. Locator devices can also be useful.
With these you attach a small electronic tag

1315.text:
to things you often mislay like keys. You
can then click a button on a locator device

1321.text:
to make the tag beep.
Having dementia can make accidents at home

1333.text:
more likely. There are a few ideas you could
consider to help you stay safe. You could

1339.text:
help prevent falls by making sure the house
is well lit and removing any trip hazards

1344.text:
like rugs. You could have hand rails fitted
on the stairs or in the bathroom. Try using

1351.text:
a personal alarm so you can alert people if
you fall.

1355.text:
It's always a good idea to install carbon
monoxide detectors and smoke alarms in the

1360.text:
home. Try using timers for your plugs, lights
and heating systems to turn things on and

1366.text:
off automatically. You could ask your local
fire service about a free home safety visit

1373.text:
to make sure your home is as safe as it can
be.

1377.text:
An occupational therapist can give advice
on items that could improve your safety and

1382.text:
help you stay independent. You can ask your
GP or memory clinic to refer you to one.

1392.text:
There can be lots of benefits to keeping as
active as possible physically, mentally, and

1402.text:
socially. It's great to meet people, it can
help you keep your skills and memory, boost

1407.text:
your self-esteem, improve sleep and avoid
depression. Activities and occupation are

1413.text:
important and make us who we are. We're all
unique in what we enjoy. Some things may become

1420.text:
more difficult and it may be tempting to give
up. However, there are often ways around things.

1427.text:
Activities such as painting, cooking, cards
and puzzles woodwork and many others can be

1432.text:
adapted or carried out slightly differently.
Carry on seeing family and friends, and try

1438.text:
to have some fun. Try taking regular physical
exercise if you can. This can include things

1445.text:
like walking and even gardening. Staying physically
healthy is also really important for people

1452.text:
with dementia. Having dementia doesn't mean
you should feel ill, depressed or anxious.

1458.text:
So it's important that you check with the
doctor if you are feeling unwell. Because

1463.text:
other illnesses and infections can make you
more confused and forgetful.

1468.text:
There are some things you can do to help with
your general health. Try to eat balanced meals

1474.text:
and drink plenty of fluids. Take regular physical
exercise if you can and get enough sleep.

1481.text:
If you smoke, have a think about stopping.
Have the flu vaccine each year and if you're

1487.text:
over 65 you can also ask your GP about the
pneumonia vaccine. Have regular check-ups

1493.text:
with the GP and also have regular sight, hearing
and dental check-ups.

1499.text:
If you find yourself regularly feeling low,
anxious or irritable, you may be depressed.

1505.text:
This can be treated so talk to someone close
to you about it. Do see your GP if it continues

1511.text:
or gets worse.
Ann: We live a perfectly normal life. We see

1514.text:
friends and family and we go out for meals
in restaurants and we entertain people and

1520.text:
go and be entertained by other people. So
we live a perfectly normal life.

1525.text:
Alice Moody: To find out more about living
well with dementia, visit alzheimers.org.uk/livingwell

1552.text:
Hilary: I think we've pretty much taken care
of the business side of things. It's really

1581.text:
when do I stop working and, I mean I want
us to have some good times together while

1587.text:
we still can. Well we will.
Ann: Very positive about the future because

1594.text:
I think I know where to go for help now because
I've listened to what they've said. I understand

1605.text:
what's happening, I understand why things
happen. I understand that it's a progressive

1609.text:
but slowly progressive disease, so it's not
going to happen overnight and it's going to

1615.text:
be slow. We've got lots of life in front of
us before it gets really bad. I'm very positive

1629.text:
about the future.
Gary Vaux: There are lots of things you can

1633.text:
do to make sure you get to choose how you
live now and in the future. Where possible,

1638.text:
make plans as early as you can with a trusted
friend, family member or professional. It

1643.text:
may get more difficult for you to make decisions
or choices about financial or legal matters

1647.text:
as time goes on. Talk to your bank about what
they can do to help. This might include arranging

1653.text:
what's called a third party mandate. This
allows someone else to deal with your account.

1659.text:
Consider setting up direct debits for regular
payments such as gas and electricity bills,

1663.text:
if you haven't done that already. If you find
it difficult to remember PINs for debit or

1668.text:
credit cards, the bank can provide alternatives
such as a chip and signature card. It's also

1674.text:
important to make sure that all your essential
documents can be found easily. This includes

1679.text:
bank accounts, mortgage or rent documents,
insurance policies, your will, tax, benefits

1684.text:
and pension details.
People with dementia and their carers may

1695.text:
be entitled to a range of benefits. Some are
means tested, which means that they depend

1700.text:
on your income or savings. Accessing them
can seem complicated but there are people

1707.text:
out there who can advise you on what to claim
for and help you complete the claim forms,

1712.text:
which can seem long and detailed.
Help may be available from a social worker

1716.text:
or a local welfare rights service, a Citizen's
Advice Bureau or Age UK, as well as the Department

1722.text:
for Social Development if you're in Northern
Ireland. The gov.uk website also provide useful

1727.text:
information. For some benefits, the Department
for Work and Pensions can arrange for someone

1732.text:
to visit you at home.
Chris Belcher: If you are able to, it will

1743.text:
help to make decisions and plans so that your
future care and finances are handled in a

1747.text:
way that reflects your wishes. It's important
to have an up to date will, as this allows

1752.text:
you to choose who inherits your money and
possessions. People with dementia can still

1756.text:
make or change a will as long as they understand
the decision they're making and the implications

1761.text:
of any changes. It may be helpful to talk
to a solicitor for advice.

1772.text:
Another way to help ensure your wishes are
carried out is to consider giving someone

1776.text:
you trust a Power of Attorney. This means
that the attorney, often a spouse or adult

1782.text:
son or daughter, can make certain decisions
on your behalf if you lose the ability to

1786.text:
do this. The legal document to set this up
in England and Wales is called a Lasting Power

1791.text:
of Attorney or LPA. There are two types of
LPA. One is for health and welfare. For decisions

1798.text:
about medical treatment, for example. The
other is for property and affairs, which gives

1803.text:
the attorney power over things like bank accounts,
bills or selling the house.

1809.text:
In Northern Ireland the law is different.
To give someone Power of Attorney in Northern

1813.text:
Ireland, you will need to make an Enduring
Power of Attorney or EPA.

1824.text:
You can choose to make decisions about your
future care in a range of other ways too.

1829.text:
Discussing views and preferences with family
and health or social care professionals is

1834.text:
called advance care planning. Advance care
planning includes one or more of the following:

1840.text:
putting in place a Lasting Power of Attorney
if you are in England and Wales, or an Enduring

1845.text:
Power of Attorney in Northern Ireland, which
I've just talked about.

1850.text:
Making an advance statement where you can
write down your priorities and preferences

1853.text:
for the future. Making an advance decision
if you are in England and Wales, or an advance

1859.text:
directive in Northern Ireland. This is a legal
document that allows you to refuse in advance,

1866.text:
specific medical treatments or procedures
in case you become unable to decide for yourself.

1872.text:
You may, for example, choose not to have your
heart or breathing restarted if they stop.

1878.text:
Discussions about care at the end of life
can be very difficult for everyone involved.

1882.text:
There shouldn't be any pressure on you to
have these discussions. However, if you are

1886.text:
thinking about advance care planning, it's
important not to leave it too late.

1899.text:
Having a diagnosis of dementia doesn’t necessarily
mean you have to stop driving straight away.

1904.text:
But if you have a driving licence, the law
says you must inform the Driver and Vehicle

1908.text:
Licencing Agency, the DVLA in Great Britain,
or the Driver and Vehicle Licencing Northern

1913.text:
Ireland DVLNI promptly about your diagnosis.
You must also tell your car insurance company.

1921.text:
The DVLA or DVLNI will request a report from
your doctor and might also ask you to take

1927.text:
a driving assessment. They will use these
to decide whether you can continue to drive.

1932.text:
Many people with dementia choose to stop driving
voluntarily. It's best to stop if you feel

1937.text:
less confident or become confused even on
familiar routes.

1942.text:
As dementia progresses, there will be a time
when stopping driving becomes essential. Stopping

1947.text:
driving can be difficult to adjust to, but
there can be some benefits. You might feel

1951.text:
less stressed and you will save money on car
insurance and fuel costs. Taking control of

1957.text:
alternative travel options, such as getting
a free bus pass, can help you with the transition.

1963.text:
As can talking through how you feel with family
and friends.

1973.text:
It is possible to continue working after a
diagnosis of dementia. Some people find working

1978.text:
helps them to feel better physically and emotionally.
Others might feel that it is the best thing

1983.text:
to do to stop. In some jobs, you are legally
obliged to tell your employer about your diagnosis,

1990.text:
so you will need to check your contract. If
you drive as part of your job, you should

1994.text:
let your employer know straight away.
You might feel anxious about telling your

1999.text:
employer about your diagnosis. But doing so
will help to give you protection under the

2003.text:
law. Once your employer knows, they must try
to make reasonable adjustments so you can

2009.text:
keep working if you are able.
Hilary: My boss was very understanding. He's

2015.text:
basically said tell me what you can do, tell
me what you can't do and we’ll see what

2020.text:
we can do to make the job work for you. The
understanding of my colleagues has been incredibly

2027.text:
helpful. It's just made such a difference
because it's out in the open and we can discuss

2033.text:
any problems we've got.
Gary Vaux: You also might be eligible for

2042.text:
a range of benefits. Depending on individual
circumstances, these can include things like

2048.text:
personal independence payment, statutory sick
pay, employment and support allowance, housing

2054.text:
benefit and council tax support. For people
with dementia who are of working age, and

2060.text:
maybe for their carer's too, some benefits
are changing. The new Universal credit will

2064.text:
replace several means testing benefits, including
Income support, Income related Employment

2069.text:
and support allowance and housing benefit.
For more information about Universal credit

2075.text:
and how it will affect you, talk to a welfare
rights service or Citizen's Advice Bureau.

2080.text:
To find out more about planning ahead, visit
alzheimers.org.uk/planningahead

2106.text:
Jim: We meet and we talk about it and I suppose
that itself is an advantage.

2134.text:
Brenda: They take the micky out of each other
and crack jokes, they're just so relaxed and

2140.text:
comfortable with it.
Ann: I had great trouble getting him out to

2144.text:
start with, he wouldn't go anywhere. But now
that he's joined all these different things

2147.text:
he has this support worker from the Alzheimer's
in Salisbury and she's very good. She comes

2152.text:
along once a week and she'll get him to go
out. She takes him out to places and they'll

2156.text:
go and have a coffee in the garden centre
or something. So he gets more of an active

2162.text:
life now than he was having.
Alex Clay: A diagnosis of dementia can be

2174.text:
daunting and raises many questions about the
future. Asking for help can feel difficult,

2180.text:
particularly if you've always been independent.
You might not feel you need it straight away

2184.text:
but it can be useful to know that a wide range
of information and support is available to

2188.text:
help you live well and stay independent for
as long as possible.

2193.text:
The main sources of information and support
are the NHS, Social Services, private companies

2198.text:
and charities and not -for-profit organisations.
To find services in your area, start by contacting

2205.text:
your local memory service. Social Services
Department, GP, Alzheimer's Society or Citizen's

2211.text:
Advice Bureau. Organisations such as Alzheimer's
Society can support people with dementia,

2216.text:
their families and carers in a range of ways.
These include dementia support workers, and

2221.text:
support groups. Telephone helplines and information
materials. Lots of different healthcare professionals

2227.text:
can support you too, such as, community nurses,
dieticians and occupational therapists who

2234.text:
help people maintain everyday skills. Social
care professionals such as social workers

2238.text:
and home carers can also offer advice.
If you need support at home, the first step

2251.text:
is to ask social services for a community
care assessment. Sometimes called a care assessment

2256.text:
or needs assessment. This aims to find ways
to help you maintain your independence and

2261.text:
quality of life and will involve a discussion
between you and someone from social services.

2267.text:
You might also be asked to fill in a questionnaire
which they can help you with if you need them

2271.text:
to.
To arrange a community care assessment you

2274.text:
or a relative or friend can contact social
services directly. Alternatively, a GP, consultant

2280.text:
or other professional involved in your care
can make a referral. Assessment information

2286.text:
and advice are always free. Social services
will appoint someone, usually a social worker,

2292.text:
to be responsible for planning your care and
support. He or she will draw up a written

2296.text:
care and support plan that looks at how they
can meet your needs.

2300.text:
They may charge you for some services, or
they may cover the costs possibly in the form

2304.text:
of a personal budget or direct payment. This
is money from the local authority that you

2309.text:
use to pay for your care and support.
If you have been diagnosed with dementia and

2321.text:
are in your 40s, 50s or early 60s, you will
have very different interests, care and support

2326.text:
needs from someone diagnosed in their 80s
or 90s. For example, younger people are more

2332.text:
likely to be working or have a partner who
is or have dependent children, or possibly

2336.text:
dependent parents and still have a mortgage.
The number of services suitable for younger

2342.text:
people is growing, but progress is slow and
services may not be available in your local

2348.text:
area. Ask your memory clinic, your consultant,
GP, your local social services about support

2353.text:
and services for younger people with dementia.
Contact Alzheimer's Society about putting

2359.text:
you, your family or carers in contact with
others in your local area, all in similar

2364.text:
circumstances. Alzheimer's Society online
discussion Talking Point, includes a section

2370.text:
for younger people with dementia and their
carers which might also be useful.

2374.text:
You might also find it helpful to visit websites
and subscribe to newsletters that support

2379.text:
people with a particular type of dementia.
To find out more about services for people

2399.text:
Caring for a supporting someone with dementia
can be stressful and at times upsetting. It

2405.text:
can also be very rewarding. It is important
that you look after your own health and wellbeing

2411.text:
and turn to others for support when you need
it.

2413.text:
Ann: Alzheimer's had a fantastic course for
carers which I did almost immediately after

2420.text:
he was diagnosed. They did one on finance,
and one on legal stuff and then they had all

2426.text:
sorts of different subjects. That was brilliant
because they taught you a lot but you could

2431.text:
also ask questions. They also had a legal
advisor come along and talk to you and a financial

2436.text:
person come along. Any questions that you
had were answered there. And if you didn't

2441.text:
have a question at the time you could always
go in a few weeks later and they'd find out

2446.text:
for you. So it was absolutely brilliant.
Alex Clay: Everyone is different but you might

2450.text:
find yourself experiencing a range of emotions
at different times. Try and take time to reflect

2456.text:
on how you're feeling and talk to someone
you trust. You might choose a professional,

2461.text:
a friend, or family member or someone at a
carer support group. If you use the internet

2467.text:
you could try an online discussion and support
forum like Talking Point. Getting support

2472.text:
will make it easier for you to cope and better
for the person you care for.

2476.text:
Sources of support for carers include family
and friends, health and social care professionals,

2482.text:
memory services, carer support groups and
organisations such as Alzheimer's Society.

2488.text:
Looking after your own health and wellbeing
is vital when you're a carer. It is important

2493.text:
to make sure that you eat a balanced diet
and to make time for regular exercise and

2497.text:
physical activity, even going for a walk can
help.

2501.text:
Make sure you see your GP about your own health
on a regular basis. If you're having problems

2506.text:
sleeping, ask them for advice. If you feel
sad or anxious a lot of the time, talk to

2512.text:
them about it as early as possible as these
could be signs of depression. Try to make

2518.text:
sure you have some regular time to relax or
do something just for yourself. This can have

2523.text:
a big impact on your wellbeing. Try to get
out regularly to meet friends. If possible,

2529.text:
consider an outing or short break which can
relieve stress and leave you feeling refreshed.

2535.text:
Find out about day care or respite support
for the person you care for. So that you can

2539.text:
take time out knowing they are well looked
after.

2543.text:
Jim: It's a help to anybody with any problem.
You've got to realise what they are like as

2556.text:
people haven't you? So one line of help will
be more beneficial say to you, than it would

2561.text:
to our friend there.
Alex Clay: Much of how you care for the person

2564.text:
will come naturally. You will probably know
the person the best and you shouldn't underestimate

2569.text:
the value you can bring to their care. It
is important to continue to see the person

2574.text:
and not just their dementia. When you help
out, focus on what they can do rather than

2580.text:
on what they can't. For example, lay clothes
out for someone to dress themselves which

2585.text:
will help to promote their independence. They
may find it hard to remember or concentrate

2590.text:
on things. So try to be flexible, tolerant
and patient. Allow extra time to do things.

2598.text:
Put yourself in their shoes. Try to understand
how they might be feeling and how they might

2603.text:
want to be cared for. Include them in conversations
and activities as much as possible. And make

2610.text:
sure they have meaningful things to do. From
every day chores to leisure activities or

2615.text:
socialising. Find things to do together if
you can. Dementia will affect a person's ability

2621.text:
to communicate. In most types of dementia
people will at times struggle to find the

2627.text:
right words or follow a conversation. This
can be upsetting and frustrating for both

2632.text:
you as a carer and the person with dementia.
Ensure that you make eye contact and listen

2639.text:
as carefully as you can. Notice your body
language and think about how you use gestures,

2644.text:
facial expressions and touch. Try to speak
clearly and if you aren't being understood,

2650.text:
use simpler words or explain things differently.
Bear in mind that other things and not just

2655.text:
dementia can affect communication. Like hearing
or eyesight problems, pain or side effects

2661.text:
of medication. If it feels right, it can sometimes
help to deal with misunderstandings and mistakes

2667.text:
using humour. But you will need to judge how
the person responds to this.

2681.text:
At times people with dementia behave differently
from how they used to. Some behaviours can

2686.text:
be particularly unusual or challenging. Behaviours
which might seem unusual include asking the

2693.text:
same question, or repeating an action over
and over, restlessness like pacing or fidgeting,

2700.text:
lack of inhibition, such as socially inappropriate
behaviour in public, and thinking someone

2705.text:
has taken something belonging to them when
they've actually mislaid it.

2710.text:
More challenging behaviours include the person
becoming very agitated or shouting out. Perhaps

2715.text:
in a response to a hallucination. The person
may also be physically or verbally aggressive.

2722.text:
While it can be very difficult, it's best
to deal with any potentially tense situations

2727.text:
as calmly as you can. Keep in mind that even
where behaviour appears to be targeted at

2732.text:
you, this may be just because you are there.
Symptoms might be caused by a curable health

2738.text:
problem such as pain, or discomfort due to
constipation or an infection. See your GP

2744.text:
if you suspect this might be the cause.
Sometimes the behaviour is really the person

2750.text:
trying to communicate an unmet need. For example,
that they are bored or frustrated. If problematic

2757.text:
behaviour persists or causes distress, seek
advice and support from your GP, memory service,

2764.text:
community mental health nurse or Admiral Nurse
who are mental health nurses who specialise

2769.text:
in dementia.
If the behaviour persists and you are not

2773.text:
in contact with a dementia specialist, ask
for a referral. Sometimes the doctor might

2779.text:
suggest medication, this may be one of the
drugs mentioned in the treatments film. If

2784.text:
these do not help your doctor may recommend
an anti-psychotic drug. If so, talk to the

2790.text:
doctor about the benefits and risks. These
drugs don't work for everyone and can have

2795.text:
serious side effects. To find out more about
support for carers, visit alzheimers.org.uk/carers

2812.text:
Alzheimer's Society is the UK's leading support
and research charity for people with dementia,

2817.text:
their families and carers. We provide a range
of services and resources to support people

2823.text:
affected by dementia. We have national services
that are available wherever you live in England,

2829.text:
Wales and Northern Ireland. These include
the National Dementia Helpline, Talking Point,

2834.text:
an online discussion forum, and our range
of information resources for people affected

2839.text:
by dementia, as well as health and social
care professionals.

2844.text:
We also offer services locally. These vary
depending on where you live and where funding

2849.text:
is available. Services include Dementia Advisers,
dementia support workers, Dementia Cafés,

2856.text:
Singing for the Brain activities, support
groups for people with dementia and support

2860.text:
groups for carers. Also available are advocacy
services, day care and home care and the carer

2867.text:
information and support programme. To find
out more about our services, please phone

2871.text:
the National Dementia Helpline on 0300 222
1122 or visit alzheimers.org.uk

2888.text:
Voiceover: Next steps checklist. This is a
list of things you can do after a diagnosis

2908.text:
of dementia that will help you to live well
now and make plans for the future.

2915.text:
Understand more about your diagnosis. For
example, the type of dementia you have and

2921.text:
what your drugs are for, if prescribed. Talk
to others about how you're feeling and ask

2928.text:
your GP if there are any therapies or activities
that could help you. Try some methods to help

2933.text:
you cope with memory loss. Introduce exercise
to your daily routine and review your diet

2947.text:
to make sure it's balanced. Organise regular
check-ups with your GP, dentist, optician

2954.text:
and chiropodist. Arrange a benefits check
for you and your carer.

2965.text:
Write or update your will and appoint an Attorney.
Tell the DVLA or DVLNI and your car insurer

2975.text:
about your diagnosis, if driving. Ask social
services for a Community care assessment and

2983.text:
a Carer’s assessment. Get in touch with
Alzheimer's Society to find out about local

2990.text:
services for you and your carer. To find out
more about The dementia guide, visit alzheimers.org.uk/dementiaguide
